707568f-b.text:
First Avenue, west side, south from E. 34th Street as
viewed from the "El" spur line thereon. View No. 2 shows a limited area, same being the S.W. and N.W. corners at E. 33rd Street.
March 23, 1928.
View 2: March 27, 1938.
P.L. Sperr

707568f-a.text:
First Avenue, west side, south from E. 34th Street as
viewed from the "El" spur line thereon. View No. 2 shows a limited area, same being the S.W. and N.W. corners at E. 33rd Street.
March 23, 1928.
View 2: March 27, 1938.
P.L. Sperr

707572f-b.text:
First Avenue, west side, north from E. 34th Street, as viewed, northwestward from the "El" spur that subsequently was razed. Shown between 35th and 36th Streets is St. Gabriels Park. In the background at the right margin is a portion of a unit of Tudor City. Note the absence of skyscrapers on the horizon.

View No. 2 is similar while No. 3 includes a portion of the easterly side of this thoroughfare with its smoke stacks of the Consolidated Edison Company generating plant. Note also in this scene the additional Tudor City units and the partial height increase of the Grand Central zone buildings.
The construction of the 39th Street East river Tunnel in 1938 still necessitated the demolition of the 4 story tenements seen on the Avenue just this side of the recently erected loft building at E. 38th Street and which appears to blend into the Tudor City outline.

March 23, 1928.
View 2: April 1928
View 3: March 21, 1929

P.L. Sperr

707584f-a.text:
New York Steam Company plant, First Avenue at 36th Street. Photo
taken from 32l East 34th Street.
September l0, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

707569f-b.text:
(1)
First Ave at the N.E. corner of 34th Street, and north.
August 2, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, seen from below 34th Street, the previous summer, showing the old house on the N.E. corner that was demolished during the intervening year. The building on the east side, south of 34th St: at the observer's right, is part of the Pennsylvania Tunnel exit. single chimney in the right of the picture belongs to the New York Steam Company's new plant on the east side of First Ave., between 35th and 36th Streets, opposite St. Gabriel's Park.
June 16, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

707576f-a.text:
First Avenue, west side, south from E. 35th to 34th Streets, showing at the corners of this block, the New York Association for the Blind workshop and the Goddard Neighborhood Center. The latter was formerly known as the Florence Baker House.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707573f-a.text:
First Avenue, east side, north from E. 34th to 35th Streets. Thru the center appears the New York Steam Co. plant on E. 35th Street between the Avenue and the East River. On the right are tenements on 34th Street,east of First Avenue. Note the bus there. This replaced the former cross town trolley cars.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority
Neg #2456

707574f-a.text:
First Avenue, west side, north from E. 34th to 36th Streets, showing several buildings occupying the lower half of this frontage, and St. Gabriel's Park the upper. The aforementioned structures are tne Goddard Neighborhood Center (formerly the Florence Baker House) and the Work Shop for Blind Men of the New York Association for the Blind.
January 7, 1939
Somach Phnoto Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712085f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, west from First Avenue. In the center, over the Second Avenue "El" station appears the Empire State Building. Note the absence of the former "El" spur line and the surface car tracks; bus transportation replacing the latter.
Jan. 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707570f-a.text:
First avenue, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of 34th Street, not long after the removal of the elevated spur on
34th Street.
September 11,1931.
P. L. Sperr.

712086f-a.text:
E. 34th Street, north side, west from First Avenue. At the right is the Goddard Neighborhood (formerly Florence Baker) House. In the center appears a 12 story loft structure, the Harriet Hubbard Ayer Building. Note at the left the Empire State building. Bus service as shown has superceded the former street cars that ran on 34th Street from river to river.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

349-345, 343-341 East 34th Street, north side, west of First Avenue.
